name: sfchronicle
text:
A fire in San Francisco‚Äôs Sunnydale housing project displaces five people Sunday evening, but is brought under control without further damage.

Story by @JohnKingSFChron: https://t.co/pJ4oanBaFs https://t.co/vWJ3e7NLun

name: sfchronicle
text:
Coronavirus contact tracing is only getting harder, the scramble to improve distance learning, and turbulent waters for one S.F. fishing boat.

Here's what you need to know to start your day: https://t.co/7yiayGw5B0 https://t.co/frvKf2AbKa

name: sfchronicle
text:
From indoor dining to local grocer: Anthony Strong, the chef and owner of San Francisco's Prairie, talks about his restaurant‚Äôs quick pivot to a general store at the onset of the coronavirus pandemic.

name: sfchronicle
text:
What can $1,000 a month do for you? And you? And you?

@JFagone talks to @DemianBulwa about what Universal Basic Income can mean for individuals, and for places like Marin City, which has been left behind by the boom.

Listen üéß:
https://t.co/JhU4AhqHfr

name: sfchronicle
text: Take Marin City and Sausalito as an example: How would these cities change if every adult got $1,000 a month, no questions asked? Reporter @JFagone takes a look at how UBI could be an equalizing force: https://t.co/4nimRuyA6J

name: sfchronicle
text: Today's front page: the stories San Francisco is talking about this morning. https://t.co/sgK7iFvtYo https://t.co/XbHs1UO6jq

name: sfchronicle
text: Hundreds of workers at Santa Rosa Memorial Hospital, including nurses, started a strike Monday morning that is expected to last five days. The hospital employees have worked without a contract for more than a year, according to union officials. https://t.co/nSsrE0RLNe https://t.co/pTIh6M5idF

name: sfchronicle
text: An experimental coronavirus vaccine in an early British trial prompted a protective immune response in hundreds of people who received it, the Associated Press reports. https://t.co/7QnEDV4nDt https://t.co/ONwYgXIBMF

name: sfchronicle
text: Alameda, Contra Costa, Marin, San Francisco, San Mateo and Santa Clara counties all fall short of their goal of doing case investigations for 90% of the people who test positive for the coronavirus. https://t.co/tqSVGm19bs

name: sfchronicle
text: For the first time, the Bay Area‚Äôs largest planning agencies have mapped what the region might look like in 2050 ‚Äî and it‚Äôs a place where new jobs and housing increasingly migrate to the South Bay. https://t.co/SqDxzbbzbT

name: sfchronicle
text: In one episode, Joseph Echema said he was watching news in the firehouse with his crew when a captain called people protesting police brutality ‚Äúa bunch of thugs‚Äù who ‚Äúdeserved to be shot by the police.‚Äù https://t.co/lUYsbpGfM4

name: sfchronicle
text: ‚ÄúIn the beginning, we thought we could do this sprint. It turns out it‚Äôs a marathon, and we don‚Äôt know if it‚Äôs going to be an ultra-marathon." https://t.co/9MjdpH4KJR

name: sfchronicle
text:
In the Bay Area, all counties except San Mateo are on the state‚Äôs coronavirus watch list, which means most school districts won‚Äôt be allowed to reopen campuses for in-person instruction.

name: sfchronicle
text: Presidential adviser Ivanka Trump advised unemployed Americans last week to ‚Äúfind something new‚Äù rather than trying to cling to the careers they had before the coronavirus struck. https://t.co/EjAhSGaBmm

name: sfchronicle
text: BREAKING: Hotel groups sue S.F. over coronavirus daily room cleaning law. The suit, being filed Monday in San Francisco Superior Court, seeks an injunction to void the Healthy Buildings ordinance.  https://t.co/BlVe4WAXEt https://t.co/rYBMbTEyJ7

name: sfchronicle
text: Mike Parson, governor of Missouri, said students should return to school where they will likely get sick with the coronavirus before going home to ‚Äúget over it.‚Äù https://t.co/iQBwBc7S0f https://t.co/DGzml3EdHc

name: sfchronicle
text: RT @SportingGreenSF: The California Interscholastic Federation ‚Äî the governing body for high school athletics in the state ‚Äî has delayed the start of all high school sports; football will end in April.  https://t.co/8oa5pnxi1P https://t.co/gR4YETNjqa

name: sfchronicle
text: For the first time, the Bay Area‚Äôs largest planning agencies have mapped what the region might look like in 2050 ‚Äî and it‚Äôs a place where new jobs and housing increasingly migrate to the South Bay. https://t.co/Vsknd0sn5w

name: sfchronicle
text: ‚ÄúWe do believe the region will rebound from this and get stronger. Any long-term plan anticipates there will be recessions and unexpected change. This one happened to come right at the start.‚Äù https://t.co/RzL4DFGmO2

name: sfchronicle
text: ‚ÄúIn the beginning, we thought we could do this sprint. It turns out it‚Äôs a marathon, and we don‚Äôt know if it‚Äôs going to be an ultra-marathon." https://t.co/n55FOlkaKP

name: sfchronicle
text: ‚ÄúI felt less of a person, I felt I didn‚Äôt deserve to be a firefighter,‚Äù he said. ‚ÄúI spent a lot of time in my car at night just thinking about how I wasn‚Äôt the right fit, that I needed to leave or go to another department.‚Äù https://t.co/3QM3EmNPTS

name: sfchronicle
text: ‚ÄúWe want to be able to have a sustained conversation with all of the contacts, but when the numbers spike up, it diminishes our ability to do that." https://t.co/4IgKKpWAKK

name: sfchronicle
text: Counties said most infected people average only about three to five close contacts, although that number has ticked up recently as shutdown orders eased. https://t.co/ftD4Y6FLev

text: As COVID-19 case numbers continue to rise around the Bay Area, there‚Äôs a clear pattern that shows younger people are growing increasingly restless and reckless in the face of the pandemic. https://t.co/O8FRxi6vkr

name: sfchronicle
text:
Anthony Strong, the chef and owner of San Francisco's Prairie, talks about his restaurant‚Äôs quick pivot to a general store at the onset of the coronavirus pandemic.

He now sells everything from toilet paper and hand sanitizer to cans of beans and pasta.
